title: truth behind the kennedy curse
story: However, it is a clan that was dogged by death long before JFK was infamously gunned down on the streets of Dallas.And  - following the overdose death of Saoirse Kennedy Hill  - the so-called family curse still appears to be casting a very dark shadow.Most people know about the shocking assassinations of President Kennedy and his brother Robert in the s.However, the scandal-hit Kennedys have suffered a string of personal tragedies which some believe is down to more than just bad luck.Now  members of the family and their spouses have died before their time - others outside the family have perished along the way.Intertwined with the shocking death toll, the family has been rocked by rape and murder scandals, claims of drugs abuse and high society marriage break-ups.Cancer has also played a role in the Kennedy family tragedies and in , Ted Kennedys -year-old son Edward Jr. lost a leg to bone cancer.He later told CNN in  he rejected the idea of a family curse.The Kennedy family has had to endure these things in a very open way. But our family is just like ... every other family in America in many ways, he said.However, here are the key dates which some say add weight to the legend of the Kennedy Curse:Joseph Patrick Kennedy Jr was killed in August  during World War II - he was just  years old.He was tragically died when his bomber aircraft exploded over Suffolk during the Second World War.Kennedy had completed  combat missions and was eligible tohome but decided to fight on.Joseph was posthumously awarded the Navy Cross, Air Medal, and Purple Heart Medal for his heroics.He was the eldest of nine children born to Joseph P. Kennedy Sr. and Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy.Kathleen Kennedy died in a plane crash four years after her high-profile wedding to the Marquess of Hartington.While working with the Red Cross, she began a romantic relationship with Lord Hartington, whom she married in May .He was killed on active service in Belgium only four months later.Kathleen, , then died in a plane crash in May , flying to the south of France while on vacation with her new partner, the th Earl Fitzwilliam.On November ,  President John F Kennedy was infamously assassinated as he rode in an open convertible through Dallas, Texas.He was killed just months after his son died just two days after he was born.Of all the events in US history, the death has probably spawned more conspiracy theories than any other.However, the official explanation is that Lee Harvey Oswald was the sole gunmanFormer US Marine Oswald was a proud communist, who briefly defected to the USSR, and was a supporter of Cuban leader Fidel Castro.He was allegedly motivated to kill the President by Kennedy’s hard line approach to Cuba including a botched invasion in  known as the Bay of Pigs.Five years after JFKs death, his younger brother Robert was assassinated after winning the Calornia Democratic primary.One June ,  he was shot and mortally wounded shortly after midnight at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles.The assassin was later named as Palestinian Sirhan Sirhan - who was apprehended immediately after opening fire with a . pistol.When detectives searched his home they found a chilling diary with the words RFK must die written over and over again.The Chappaquiddick incident refers to a bizarre car crash that occurred in Massachusetts on July , .The late-night accident was caused by Senator Ted Kennedys negligence and resulted in the death of his -year-old passenger Mary Jo KopechneAccording to Kennedys testimony, he accidentally drove his car off the one-lane bridge and into the tide-swept Poucha Pond.He swam free, left the scene, and did not report the accident to the police for ten hours Kopechne died inside the fully submerged car.The story became global news and is believed to have influenced Kennedys decision not to campaign for President in  and .David Kennedy was the fourth child of Robert F Kennedy and aged just  when he watched his dad gunned down on live TV.As a child, he was shy, introverted and sensitive, and shared a particularly strong bond with his father.His fathers shocking assassination left a deep emotional scar on young David and he turned to drugs in his early teens.By  he was dead aged  after overdosing on cocaine, Demerol and Mellaril in a Palm Beach hotel room.On New Years Eve , Michael Kennedy, the sixth of RFKs children, was killed in a skiing accident in Colorado.He was playing American football on skis with his pals when he suddenly crashed into a tree in Aspen, Colorado.The -year-old was not wearing a helmet or any other kind of safety equipment, an inquest later revealed.Michael was just five years old when his uncle was assassinated and  when his dad was also shot dead.John F Kennedy Junior, JFKs son, died while flying his light aircraft to the holiday island of Marthas Vineyard.He reportedly became disoriented during the night flight and then crashed into the ocean on July , .He was travelling with his we Carolyn and sister-in-law Lauren Bessette to attend the wedding of his cousin.All three perished in the tragedy.Johns father was assassinated just three days before his third birthday.Mary Richardson Kennedy, the estranged we of Robert Kennedy Jr, died after reportedly hanging herself at home on May , .Her husband, Robert Kennedy Jr, a prominent environmental lawyer and the son of former senator Robert F Kennedy, had filed for a orce two years earlier.The two had married in  and had four children together. The orce case was still pending at the time of her death.In the months after the couples separation became public, Mary Kennedy was arrested twice by police officers who suspected her of driving while drunk.The most recent victim of the so-called curse was Robert F. Kennedy’s granddaughter Saoirse who died from a suspected drug overdose at her family’s home in Cape Cod.Saoirse Kennedy Hill, , is understood to have gone into cardiac arrest at the compound where her grandmother Ethel Kennedy, , lives.Paramedics rushed to the home on Thursday and took her to Cape Cod Hospital, where she was pronounced dead, the New York Times reports.“Our hearts are shattered by the loss of our beloved Saoirse,” the Kennedy family said in a statement.“Her le was filled with hope, promise and love.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: botox stop men premature ejaculation
story: Researchers found the muscle-relaxing jabs helped rats last almost four-times longer on average.And they believe the treatment will work just as well in fellas who struggle to control their excitement.Premature ejaculation affects  per cent of men and is the most common sexual dys in young lads.Turkish scientists tested the power of Botox jabs – typically used to ease facial wrinkles – in  male rodents.Some received a single dose of the toxin injected into a muscle near their privates and some received five doses.A final control group was not injected.The boffins, from Balikesir University, then stimulated the rats and timed how long it took them to peak.Those given a single dose lasted .-times longer than the untreated group. And those given five doses lasted .-times longer.Study leader Dr Sakir Ongun said the effects of Botox can last up to nine months in humans.He added: “Injection of botulinum-A toxin into the bulbospongiosus muscle in rats signicantly delayed the ejaculation latency time.“We suggest that botulinum-A toxin should be considered in the treatment of premature ejaculation.“Although premature ejaculation is a common disease, treatment options remain limited.”Sex therapists say romps that last three to seven minutes are “adequate” and seven to thirteen minutes “desirable”.Anything shorter or longer may disappoint, a poll found.The research findings are published in the Journal of Sexual Medicine. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thai king mistress royal consort
story: King Maha Vajiralangkornm, , used ceremonial water to anoint his long-term girlfriend Sineenat Wongvajirapakdi, , while she lay at his feet on Sunday.This is the first time in the countrys modern history that a monarch has publicly admitted to having more than one partner.Sineenat, who is the King’s former bodyguard, was given the title of chao khun phra meaning royal noble consort during the ceremony which marked his birthday.His new we Queen Suthida, who was sat next to her husband during the televised service, showed no emotion as Vajiralongkorn splashed water on his fancy woman.The mistress lay on the floor at her lover’s feet during the ceremony, in accordance with Thailand’s royal tradition.This is the first time a Thai king has practised polygamy since the end of the absolute monarchy in .Sineenat also received four medals, including the most noble order of the crown of Thailand and the most exalted order of the white elephant, special class.Vajiralongkorn also praised her work as senior officer in his personal bodyguard, the Ratchawallop Police Retainers.Sineenat, known as Koi, also holds the rank of major-general and was born Niramon Ounprom.She formerly worked as a nurse at the Ananda Mahidol army hospital.Her elevation comes less than three months after the monarch’s marriage to former Thai Airways stewardess Suthida, , known as Nui, who had been his consort for some years.In May, official photos showed Queen Suthida laying on the floor as she was given a gt by the king during her wedding ceremony to the monarch.The surprise announcement was carried in the Royal Gazette and footage from Wednesdays wedding ceremony was later shown on the nightly Royal News segment aired on all Thai television channels.Vajiralongkorn, , also known by the title King Rama X, became constitutional monarch after the death of his revered father, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, in October , after  years on the throne.He is due to be officially crowned in elaborate Buddhist and Brahmin ceremonies on Saturday, followed by a procession through Bangkok the next day.In , Vajiralongkorn appointed Suthida Tidjai, a former flight attendant for Thai Airways, as a deputy commander of his bodyguard unit.Some royal observers and foreign media had linked Suthida romantically with the king, but the palace had previously never acknowledged a relationship between them.The king made Suthida a full general in the Royal Thai Army in December , and the deputy commander of the kings personal guard in . He also made her a Thanpuying, a royal title meaning Lady during the lavish ceremony.However, the kings pristine ceremonial outfit was a far cry from the outrageous croptop and low-slung jeans he was once spotted wearing while wandering around a German shopping centre.The monarch even threatened to sue Facebook over the startling shots, taken in  by a passer-by who recognised the king.The images, which appeared to show Maha out for a stroll with a girlfriend while wearing fake tattoo “sleeves”, fall foul of Thailand’s extremely strict law of “lese-majeste” — or insulting royalty.But the king’s bizarre dress sense is just the tip of the iceberg for this clearly very dferent monarch.Indeed, his string of failed marriages and apparently insatiable appetite for women - his own mother Queen Sirikit branded him a womaniser - has had Thais quietly gossiping for years.During a  trip to the US, Sirikit said: “My son, the Crown Prince, is a little bit of a Don Juan.He is a good student, a good boy, but women find him interesting and he finds women even more interesting.”Maha has ruled Thailand since the death last year of his father who was married to Sirikit for  of those years.But in stark contrast to his father, Brit-educated Maha has already orced three times - and is now on his FOURTH we.In  he married his first we — his cousin, Princess Soamsawali Kitiyakara.They had a daughter, Bajrakitiyabha, but the relationship was doomed from the start.During the marriage Maha fathered four sons and a daughter with his mistress, actress Yuvadhida Polpraserth.They began living together but his we refused to orce him.Finally, in , he sued for orce, laying the blame for the failed relationship entirely at Soamsawali’s feet.He married Yuvadhida the following year but after a mysterious bust-up two years later, she fled to the UK to escape her husband.Livid Maha ordered posters to be placed all around his palace accusing her of adultery with a -year-old Thai air marshal.The prince then had his daughter brought back to Thailand. His four sons say they were banned from ing by their father.In a letter written in  they said: “We were ordered by our father not tohome to Thailand. We were afraid to risk even demonstrating the slightest inference of disrespect toward the Royal Family.”In  the king married his third we — former waitress Srirasmi Suwadee, who had been in his service since .He kept the marriage secret from the public until , when she gave birth to their son, Prince Dipangkorn Rasmijoti.Maha even told a magazine it was his intention to settle down.The pair bought a poodle, Foo Foo, which Maha became devoted to in a way that even the most ardent dog lover would find extreme.He made it an Air Chief Marshal in the Royal Thai Air Force and the dog appeared at official s dressed in a dinner jacket.In  Foo Foo was a guest at a reception held by the US Ambassador Ralph Boyce.In a leaked document, Mr Boyce said: “Foo Foo was present at the event, dressed in formal evening attire complete with paw mitts.“At one point during the band’s second number, he jumped up on to the head table and began lapping from the guests’ water glasses, including my own.“The Air Chief Marshal’s antics drew the full attention of the -plus audience members, and remains the talk of the town to this day.”Foo Foo hit the headlines once again when a video from its birthday party surfaced online.It appears to show topless Srirasmi lying on the floor in just a G-string, feeding cake to the dog.She sings Happy Birthday to it before getting on her hands and knees and eating from the same bowl as Foo Foo.When the dog died in  Maha gave it a four-day funeral complete with Buddhist rites before it was cremated in a lavish ceremony.A year earlier he orced Srirasmi, stripped her royal titles and exiled her to an undisclosed location in Thailand — with a reported settlement of £.m.He then jailed her parents for two-and-a-half years for “royal defamation”. Soon afterwards he hooked-up with his latest we Vajiralongkorn - who is nicknamed Nui.Among the dignitaries at their wedding were Prayuth Chan-ocha, the leader of the military junta that has run Thailand since a  army coup.While the king took the throne after the death of his father, his formal coronation follows a mourning period for King Bhumibol, whose royal cremation was held a year after his death.

story: Bethany Joseph, , was on a night out with friends in Yarm, North Yorks, when she clashed with another woman while queuing for the toilet.The pair bumped into each other on December  and the victim told Joseph: “Why are you pushing  You want to be careful.”Moments later a fight broke out in the Hide Bar toilets and Joseph told cops she “let go” of her glass and it “must have hit her on the head”.Joseph, then a third-year psychology student at Teesside University, said: “I dont remember who grabbed whose hair first.“I had a glass in my hand. Ms Johnsonaposs bravery has now been described as stunning by her husband Matthew Smith. He told the Daily Mail:  Sheaposs our Wonder Woman. We are all so proud of her. She has been through a harrowing, awful ordeal and she just needs time and space to recover. Ruth was going out of her way to chaperone the poor girl and tried with all of her strength to save her le.    Ruthaposs bravery was stunning. But at the end of it all, a family has lost a daughter. Thataposs foremost in all our minds. Mr Smith added that everyone is so proud of Ruth but she is still coming to terms with what she witnessed, adding it will stay with her for the rest of her le. Ms Johnson had spent three weeks in Madagascar teaching in remote village schools and donating clothes, games, books and classroom equipment. She was staying at the Anjajavy Le Lodge in the north of the island where she met Alana, whose mental health had reportedly started to deteriorate. Alana was due to stay for  days while working on a conservation project investigating crabs in the nature reserve in the north of the island.    But the Biological Natural Sciences student decided tohome after just eight days after suffering a series of panic attacks. At the request of Alanaaposs parents, Ms Johnson was accompanying her home when the tragedy unfolded on July , just five minutes into the two hour and  minute flight. It is understood Alana unbuckled her seatbelt, leaned forward and turned the door handle prompting the pilot to desperately try and close it. Ms Johnson then tried to stop Alana from falling out, but was battling the wind and rocking of the plane. Pilot Mahefa Tahina Rantoanina, , said the teenager stayed “completely silent during the horrying incident. He told The Sun: “I had just taken off and I was still climbing when all of a sudden there was a rush of wind and Ruth started screaming. I turned round and saw Alana hanging out of my plane.    “I immediately levelled the aircraft to try and keep us on course, then I reached over and held the door. “I was trying to pull it shut while Ruth was holding on to Alana’s leg. I was trying to fly and stop her from falling at the same time. I was absolutely terried, we all were. Extensive searches to try and locate Alana in an area which includes a lake, dense forest, woodland and swamps have so far proved fruitless. As we previously reported, Alana was mumbling and incoherent in the days before her death, according to her uncle, Lester Riley.    He said she had became sick during her time in Madagascar, possibly due to prescription medication, although reports have claimed police are investigating her possible use of an anti-malaria drug. He told MailOnline: She had taken ill after being there for a few days and when she spoke to her mother on the phone two days before the accident she was mumbling and sounded pretty incoherent. We think she had suffered a severe reaction to some drugs but not anti-malaria ones because she had taken those on her trip last year to China without any side effects. One of Alanaaposs friends also claims the Brit sounded upset in a final phone call to her mum and said: Me, plane, home. A source claimed to the Sun: Alana was taking a type of malaria drug and police are working on a theory that is what was sending her delirious. Her last phone call to her mum wasnapost like her at all. It didnapost make sense. She wasnapost in the right frame of mind and it was unlike any normal conversation she would have had.

title: what its really like being
story: NewsThis is what its really like being in the crowd at a ,-person Trump rallyMirror’s man in US enters fray at Trump rally to see why supporters love himShareCommentsByChristopher Bucktin:,  AUG NewsPresident Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally in Cincinnati, Ohio "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStanding among the crowd wearing Make America Great Again caps and T-shirts while some of them screamed “Shove gun control up your a**” and “Trump Rambo”, I was nervous. Typically I’d cover Donald Trump’s rallies from either behind the penned barricades or from the safety of a live feed off a TV news channel. But this time it was dferent. For, after braving five hours waiting to board the Trump Train at the President’s latest  re-election rally, I joined thousands of his supporters in Cincinnati’s C heat to become just another face in the crowd. Like the President, I was more interested in how his base responded, and to what, opting this time to just listen to what they were saying to each other, and to Trump, instead of fact-checking his every word.  The President wasn’t scheduled to take to the stage until pm but by .pm, after being patted down by the Secret Service, I’d taken my seat stage right. Sitting alongside the Deplorables, as Hillary Clinton labelled Trump’s supporters, I was told by farmer and uber Trump fan Nick Pepper to expect “fireworks”. “This will be like nothing you’ve ever seen before,” the three-time rally veteran told me. “He’s our leader and we believe in what he says. “If President Trump says we need a wall, we need a wall. “If he says send those who don’t like our country home, send them home. “He delivers on his promises.” As , filled the US Bank Arena, the die-hard crowd were played like a symphony orchestra as Team Trump whipped supporters into a frenzy as they waited for their messiah. One-by-one, local politicians and judges – yes, they are political here – took to the stage to tell why the President should be re-elected on November  next year, only then for the real warm-up act to enter. Grinning inanely like a constipated Cheshire Cat, Don Trump Jr, swaggered his way to the podium. Having torn himself away from the killing fields and put down his big-game hunting rles, the President’s eldest child picked up his political pistols to fire off volley after volley of attacks on his father’s critics. Whether it be Trump’s political opponents, cities which his dad had attacked, immigration or mocking Joe Biden, nothing was off-limits. Then, after what seemed like the entire Rolling Stones back catalogue, Survivor’s Eye of the Tiger kicked in and the crowd knew the king of bungle was due on stage. He swaggered on like a power-hungry Roman emperor, giving the same thumbs-up Caesar gave in his adoring amphitheatres. As he paced the walkway and smiled and waved, the crowd leapt to its feet and roared, waving campaign-provided signs reading, “Jobs Jobs Jobs” and “Women for Trump”. But it didn’t take long before the President was throwing political red meat to the baying crowd who applauded his every sentence, boast and lie. They reached their thunderous loudest quickly, however, when several protesters showed their hand. In unison, like a military-run pack of hyenas, the crowd turned on them as they held up posters reading, “Immigrants Built America”. The protesters’ cries that Trump was a racist were drowned by chants of “USA, USA,” and “Trump, Trump, Trump,” before the President told “law enforcement” to move in. Quickly, the US leader got back on message. He mocked rival Democrats for attacking former President Barack Obama during a debate this week and got in hits at rivals Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren during his remarks. But it was the behaviour of the crowd that I and the world were watching, following last month’s rally in North Carolina. There, Trump had continued his racist broadside at a foursome of Democratic congresswomen of colour known as The Squad, telling them to “go back” to the countries they came from – even though three of them were born in the States. Trump supporters at that rally increased the attack with chants of “send her back”. This time, Cincinnati’s crowd offered their fair share of boos, cheers of “USA”, “build the wall,” and even ed to the  campaign chant regarding Hillary Clinton, screaming “lock her up”. But they didn’t go as far as the Carolina supporters, as Trump told the arena: “We want no controversy”. He did, however, blame “the far-left’s destructive agenda” for poverty and crime in inner cities, increasing his effort to tie Democrats to poor neighbourhoods. Trump accused his rivals of prioritising undocumented immigrants over American citizens, called Calornia “a disgrace to our country” and sought to talk up his efforts to improve minority communities. “For decades, these communities have been run exclusively byDemocrat politicians and it’s been total one-party control of the inner cities,” he said. “For  years it’s been one-party control and look at them. We can name one after another but I won’t do that because I don’t want to be controversial.” Trump’s remarks were a clear reference to his recent attacks on Elijah Cummings, the black Democratic lawmaker whose Baltimore district Trump described as “rat and rodent-infested” and a place where “no human being would want to live”.  Trump belittled the Maryland city, a majority-black borough, claiming its murder rate is higher than war-torn Afghanistan. Tellingly, the vast majority in the arena were white – I counted no more than  African Americans. For an hour and  minutes, Trump rambled along, at times incoherently ignoring the autocue, but he knows how to sell himself to his crowd.  His repealing of the Iran nuclear deal, his scuttling of the Paris accords and the moving of the US embassy to Jerusalem, he insisted, had “restored American pride”. “Keep America great again,” he boomed, as he closed his show. The salesman in Trump had sold Cincinnati precisely what they wanted to hear.

story: The congregation of a city church are doing their bit to help save lives by purchasing a potentially lesaving device for the community.Parishioners at Holburn West Church have bought a public-access defibrillator which,needed, could save the le of someone suffering heart problems.The device will be available for any member of the public to use while the church is open.It will also be logged on the Scottish Ambulance Service’s national database – enabling  operators to direct callers to the nearest defibrillator and dramatically increase the chance of survival.The church’s joint session clerk, city councillor Martin Greig, said churchgoers had taken inspiration from Scandinavia.He said: “We were given a really interesting piece of information about Norway.“Someone there who suffers heart problems has a much higher chance of survival because there is a higher number of defibrillators available to the public.“The congregation decided they want to follow that example and have a defibrillator here to be usedit is needed.“More and more churches and organisations are installing defibrillators because there is much more awareness of the importance of them and the vital role they play in saving lives.”Mr Greig added: “It’s an important public health issue and we are trying to be responsible citizens by making sure we do this.“We want there to be as many of these as possible in the city.“You hope it’s something that is never needed but it is thereit is.”A defibrillator gives reassurance in case of an emergency, said Mr Greig.He added: “It dramatically increases the chance of a good outcome.”The device was provided by Stuart Gordon of Inverurie-based firm SMG Safety who also trained members of the congregation on how to use the vital piece of equipment.Stuart said: “The statistics show that, for every minute without defibrillation, your chances of survival are dropping by a massive %. However,you can get a defibrillator on the casualty within three minutes, your chances can go up to an encouraging %.“It is great that the church has installed this le-saving piece of equipment as the ious halls within the church are used by a number of community groups.“This will give everyone peace of mind and ensure they can do everything they can should anything like this occur in the building.”

title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

story: Barabel McKayUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsLast year we were studying the Argyll and Bute Health and Social Care Partnership#Transforming Together#   document, which presented a vision of combining our will and skills to create a healthy future for the citizens of Argyll.The promises in that did not translate into reality.Now, a  beautully constructed and presented Living Well document is available. It runs to  pages, and must have taken signicant time and money to produce.It relies heavily on community participation and the Third Sector Interface .While it was being prepared the HSCP was in the process of getting rid of volunteer forums, TSI was shedding staff and Guided Self Help was being transferred to the NHS Mental Health Team, while essential services are still dependent on successful bids for money.Planning must not be a substitute for provision. In Living Well we are told that hypertension is by far the most common long-term condition. This area lacks the yearly health checks which might lead to early detection and intervention.The initiative and enthusiasm of hospital staff in improving mobility have already been commended, but the dearth of professional rehabilitation services in the community is nothing short of a disgrace.Everyone  seems to recognise this # indeed at a recent housing conference the keynote speaker highlighted the need for intervention to halt the downward slide into dependency. In an English trust they have even  appointed a physiotherapist to identy reversible causes of frailty.We have to fight complacency about our own health and in the attitudes of our health care providers.To contact Mid Argyll Health and Care Forum, email the forum chairperson Barabel McKay at barabelmck@gmail

title: kilmartin twinshocks race report
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Jim GrieveRace day on the iconic former Grand Prix track at Carnasserie Castle on June  started off on a sombre note, as riders all paid respects with a minute of silence for fallen riding legendary Ian ‘Lugs’ Robertson.Many riders sported Ian’s riding number  on their bikes.The racing started with group one and the flying EVO cc class with Peter O#Neil, and William Penrice showing the bigger bikes how it should be done. Peter O#Neil edged out Penrice in race one, but Penrice would take his revenge in race two and it was all to play for in the final encounter. Peter O#Neil was up to the task and would take the overall, with Penrice a deserved second and  Damian Carter would third.The four stroke class was enthralling, with Sam Sibbald thundering around the Kilmartin track, big Andy Malloch and his Armstrong chasing him all the way to the flag and winning the final race but not the overall. Sam would be the victor followed by Andy and a consistent Keith Stanford third.For the youth class it was a day of mixed fortunes and consistency would be the key, with Jordan Graham coming out on top ahead of James Forrest and picking up a superb third overall was Rhys Brown.Pre- action would see committee man and track builder Grant McClure and his Maico, with three decades of riding under his belt, become the overall winner ahead of Callum Wilson on the superbly prepared Honda.The Twinshock under cc event would be a three race win for the flying Calum Kilgour and his cc Yamaha ahead of Jim Grieve, who would have some bike issues but would bring home his Honda in second fighting off a very persistent David Lawson and Gordon Peterson but it would be Gordon that would hold the third place trophy with some consistent riding.The Twinshock open class event would be a spectacular sight as cc Hondas and Maicos battled their way around the bracken.In race one there was a very small gap between first and second place and a similarly small gap between third. Brian Alexander would take the win from Craig ‘Smitch’ Smith, and John Crawford would come home in third with a notable mention to the very unlucky Paul Chiappa who had his fair share of misfortunes throughout the day, as his seat was torn from his bike at the top of one of the steep climbs. The overall would end up the same as the first race with Brian, taking the win from Craig Smith and John Crawford bringing the big Honda home in third.In the over s class it was a triumphant day for John Lamont with three resounding victories. Johnny Rutherford was second, a great result for the club sponsor, with David Watson bringing home the Honda with some consistent rides.For the group three races Robert Bell took the honours from Allan Shields and Bryan Colligan, all of these riders deserving a notable mention and with some very similar lap times and some quick racing in trying conditions.The clubman class was great to watch, with some fast up-and-coming riders such as Peter Rennie, Callum Laird and Stuart Wilson all angling for the win. Rennie would take the overall from Laird in second and  Wilson in third.The evolution class was again the Paul and Tom show. In what must have been the fastest racing all day, it would be Paul #PJ# Johnston who would take overall honours with three wins and Tom Grant would take the runner-up slot followed home ably by a consistent Roy Potts taking the third place.In the final block of racing it would be a win apiece for Jordan McDonald, Shaun Robertson, and John Kenny, but it would be the ever improving Shaun Robertson, ing from injury, who would take overall honours from a rapidly improving John Kenny in second and #Mr Consistent# Karl Livingstone in third.Results:Group Pre- class:  Grant McClure  Callum Wilson. title: tayvallich celebrates summer in style
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowTayvallich is set for a fortnight of celebration, centred around the annual gala weekend at the end of July.The action kicks off on Thursday July  when Balter, one of the most feted bands on the folk circuit,to the stage at the Village Hall. Balter are a contemporary folk quartet who have emerged from the music scene in Newcastle but are strongly influenced by their shared love of Scottish music.These four multi-talented womenfollow up their success at Glasgow’s Celtic Connections festival and as finalists in the Battle of the Folk Bands in Edinburgh to bring their exuberance and infectious live energy back to Tayvallich after a barnstorming gig there a year ago.Playing music from Shetland, the Borders, the Western Isles and Ireland, from foot-stomping jigs and reels to soulful Gaelic melodies, the foursome combine traditional and original material. The interplay between fiddles, mandolin and accordion creates a distinctive sound of intricate arrangements that mixes Balter’s traditional heritage with contemporary influences.The celebrations continue when the Tayvallich Big Weekend gets under way on Friday July  with a barbeque and live music at the Tayvallich Inn. The focus moves to the village hall on Saturday July .Starting at am, there are games sports stalls from local businesses, voluntary groups and organizations and fabulous food and drink. Pooches both pedigree and potpourri have their day at the ever-popular Dog Show.The Family Ceilidh on Saturday evening has live music from the exhilarating Argyll Ceilidh Trail band. The weekend is rounded off on Sunday morning with the World Crab Fishing Championship on the Tayvallich village pontoon.The party continues on Wednesday July , when gypsy jazz quartet Latchepen roll up. Latchepen are a London-based gypsy jazz outfit comprising four musicians from dferent corners of the globe, brought together by a shared admiration of Django Reinhardt and all that swings. Latchepen is an exclamation of happiness and contentment in the Romani language. Acoustic by nature but with projection and a heartbeat that rival any amp or drum, this is jazz on a string with influences ranging from Romani music to bebob.Fun, games, music, food and drink # Tayvallich is the place to be this month.Balter will rock Tayvallich on Thursday July  at pm before Latchepen gets everyone dancing on Wednesday July  at pm. Tickets are £at the door or email info.tayvhall@gmail.The venue is unlicensed but you are welcome to bring your own bottle.

title: northern jolly for loch fyne anglers
story: Nikki ThompsonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe Loch Fyne Sea Angling Club couldn’t have asked for better weather for its annual soirée to the fertile fishing grounds of Stornoway.The crossing from Ullapool was as smooth as you like and a sure sign we were in for a good couple of days. Day one saw us head out from Carloway aboard the SYSAC II under the watchful eye of skippper Robbie Bell who knows these waters like the back of his hand.The day kicked off with a bait hunt in the East Loch but the mackerel were pretty scarce, it took an hour or so to fill the baskets before steaming out to the two-mile mark in search of spurdogs. By then there was a fair wee wind picking up and it was a tad rough to say the least, with the heavy swell claiming a few breakfasts along the way.All that was soon forgotten as the battle commenced with the mighty spurs. The action started on the first drop with some thumpers coming aboard, single and double shots causing mayhem thrashing about the deck and we lost count of the number of rigs sliced through on the way up. But that’s what we came for, not everyone’s choice but great sport all the same.In between the madness we picked away at the haddock, whiting, grey and red gurnard, ling and pollack, until we had our quota and decided to seek the smoother waters of East Loch Roag for some flattie bashing on the soft ground. It was good to get into the calm and fish the light gear, picking away for dabs and plaice. There was plenty around, nothing huge but a steady flow coming aboard taking us to the end of the day with a good mixed bag of species.Day two set off in brilliant sunshine and not a breath of wind, it was almost tropical conditions. We quickly got our supply of fresh bait in West Loch Roag and set off for the rough ground in search of a few more species, but there was little or no drt so we took a turn into Clf Bay and settled in for a day on the rays. It was brilliant fun, everyone got their fair share with loads of thornback rays and a few spotted rays coming aboard, plenty of dabs, plaice, dogfish and a bonus lb oz turbot to add to the tally. It was a great opportunity to brush up on some of fishing techniques that don’t get practised much at home.We decided to hit the hard ground on the way back to the harbour. It was quite slow, maybe a wee bit early yet, but it produced more haddock, a lovely lb cuckoo wrasse and pollack bringing our two day adventure to an end. All in all another excellent club trip.This year we picked up  species,  counting fish and a few personal bests. Add to that, great company, loads of banter, a good skipper who makes a mean cup o’ tea and you have the ideal ingredients for another memorable few days away on Lewis. We’ll be back next year for sure.Results: Nikki Thompson  points, Robert MacBrayne , Nick Friel , Jim Smith , Gary Sinclair , Steven MacBrayne .

Some older cars rely on  ron petrol and with the replacement of the pumps in the Esso garage, drivers will be forced to drive almost  miles to Dunbeg, by Oban, or  miles to Helensburgh.Lochgilphead resident Lockhart Leitch raised the issue with MSP Michael Russell who contacted Esso for a response.A spokesperson for Esso said: #We recently replaced the pumps at the Tesco Esso Lochgilphead service station, removing supreme unleaded and replacing it with supreme diesel in addition to the regular unleaded and diesel products.#Sales of regular diesel make up two thirds of all fuel sales at this site, therefore having this additional diesel grade provides an alternative option for a bigger proportion of our customerswe experience dficulties with replenishing regular diesel stocks when the weather challenges us to reach Lochgilphead.#Although it would be a long drive, we can offer a supreme unleaded grade at Helensburgh Express as well as a site near Oban.#We continually review the fuel offerings at all our sites but at the current time we have no plans to reinstate supreme unleaded at Lochgilphead. We did advise the community with two weeks notice of our plans to close the forecourt during the works, however, I note we could have done better in providing advance notice of the grade change specically and we will endeavour to provide notices on site in advance of any future changes.#MSP Michael Russell said: #I would be concernedthere was a reduction in choice in any of the garages. If people need  ron they should be able to get it locally, particularly where there is more than one petrol station.#Narrowing the choice and making people drive to buy petrol is never a good idea.#In response, Lockhart Leitch said: #The reply from Esso is, to my mind, a typical big company response. They are entitled to change productsthey are not selling as they would like, however, to change from Supreme petrol to Supreme diesel without at least notying customers in advance that Supreme unleaded will no longer be sold is diabolical.#

title: inchorus-aim-another-sell-out-fringe
story: PEEBLES community choir InChorus is making a welcometo the Edinburgh Fringe next month.And the singers are hoping to continue their remarkable record of selling out venues during the international arts festival.For the past three years the talented singers have wowed audiences from around the world in the capital.And anyone lucky enough to have a ticket for the Assembly Roxy Centralon the evening of Wednesday, August  will no doubt experience yet another wondrous performance.Choir manager Lorna Turnbull said: ldquoThis will be our fourth Fringe concert and at all our previous appearances we have been thrilled to find that a great proportion of our audiences came from Tweeddale."We hope to welcome a large home crowd again."Their support is what keeps us going and is never taken for granted.Rehearsals have been ongoing over the summer ahead of the annual Fringe performance.Excitations with InChorus showcases exciting new material together with some well-known crowd pleasers, all especially arranged for the large eight-part choir.In a largely acapella performance there will be songs from all around the globe, together with numbers by Queen, Camila Cabello, Enya, Billy Joel, the Beach Boys, George Ezra, a Motown mash-up, ending with an exhilarating celebration of InChorusrsquo wonderful ten plus years.Musical Director,Aly Skidmore told us: ldquoAs always, the choir offers its own unique mix of inspiring contemporary music."Therersquos everything from pop to world music, and traditional to modern classical."Combined with InChorusrsquo vibrant performance style, we guarantee that the audience will have a stimulating, rousing and toe-tapping time, ensuring that levels of excitement are raised considerably during the hour, and that people leave titillated totally.Following their three previous performances, InChorus received the much coveted Fringe lsquoSell-out Showrsquo laurel.And members are hoping they can make it four sold-out appearances in a row.Excitations with InChorus is on at Assembly Roxy Central,  Roxburgh Place, Edinburgh EH SUon August  at .pm.Tickets cost pound and are available from Assembly Roxy on    or from title: boost-kidney-charity-closed-road-cycling-events-returns
story: ONE of the regions biggest sporting events is ing to Peebles this autumn.And a leading kidney charity is also set to benefit.Despite protests in the past over the extent of disruption, the Tour O The Borders closed road cycling event will take place in .And yet again more than , cyclists will descend on the region on September .This year, event organisers Hillside Outside Ltd have teamed up with Kidney Research UK as their official charity partner.It was the inspirational story of regular Tour O The Borders participants, father and son duo Tim and Joseph McLean, that ignited the partnership.The pair had to withdraw from the  event due to Joseph, only , being diagnosed with end stage kidney failure.Fortunately, father Tim was a suitable tissue match for Joseph, and both are now fully recovered from a kidney transplant operation.Deep into their training for Tour O The Borders , Tim said: ldquoJoseph and I are hugely relieved to have the opportunity tothis year."This is all thanks to the fantastic work of the fabulous renal and transplant teams of the NHS of whom we will be eternally grateful."Much of their work is supported by research funded by Kidney Research UK who have the potential to improve the lives of the three million people with kidney disease in the UK."Joseph and Tim are among the lucky ones who were a good match for an early transplant, an ode to their good health largely due to their love of cycling and participating in events such as Tour O The Borders.ldquoWe have many things to be grateful for and good health is top of the list," Tim added.ldquoWe look forward to meeting up with many old and new friends and a great day of cycling in September and hopefully raise some money for this very worthy cause.Hillside Outsides marketing manager, Harley Lothian, is delighted to announce the partnership.She said: ldquoTim and Joseph reached out to us earlier this year and we were so inspired by their story that we wanted to do what we could to raise awareness of this fantastic charity, and ultimately educate people on the benefits that being physically fit can have in such a situation."Tour O The Borders , powered by Pirelli, takes place on September .The event attracts more than  cyclists every year, who choose between routes of km or km.Donations can be made at tourotheborders and on the day of the event.

title: contractors-saddle-new-hawick-cycleway
story: DETAILED plans for a new cyclepath through Hawick have been submitted with Scottish Borders Council.Approval was granted at the end of  for a new Flood Protection Scheme for the town, which included the provision of a shared-used cycleway.But five of the six sections of the . kilometre pathway requires inidual permission due to the scale of works.The pathway from Volunteer Park to Oliver Park will be designed so it is suitable for a -year-old cyclist to use unaccompanied.And it will feature railings and a shelter at strategic points along the Teviot.Several existing paths will be realigned under the proposals and the entire route will have a width of between three and four metres.Contractors Jacobs have now applied for a screening response from the local authority before progressing with the scheme.

title: melrose-abbey-goes-green-highlight-call-action
story: ONE of Scotlandrsquos most iconic landmarks turned green last week in support of a lsquonet zerorsquo nation.Melrose Abbey was illuminated as part of SP Energy Networkrsquo major plans to support a low carbon Scotland.In lighting many of Scotlandrsquos landmarks green, SPEN is urging businesses, local authorities and public bodies to consider what lsquogoing greenrsquo will mean for them and how their organisations will need to innovate in the future.Last year, ScottishPower became the first integrated energy company in the UK to sht completely from coal and gas generation to wind power ndash becoming % green.And now SPEN has revealed key plans to help cities, towns and rural communities across the country achieve lsquonet zerorsquo to support the Scottish Government achieving the worldrsquos most ambitious target, cutting greenhouse gas emissions to zero by .The switch-on coincided with SPEN hosting an awards event at Edinburghrsquos Dynamic Earth to present pound million funding to innovative projects selected for investment through its Green Economy Fund.They granted the funding boost to  projects including e-bike and e-bus schemes, low carbon energy systems, community hubs and renewable energy training courses across Scotland.The event was the second of its kind as through the first round of funding a few Borders organisations have already benefited.One of which was the Ettrick and Yarrow Community Development Company, who are in the process of buying an electric people carrier for the Valleys.Frank Mitchell, Chief Executive of SP Energy Networks, said: ldquoBecoming net zero offers Scotland a huge economic opportunity.ldquoThe road to  will mean many everyday activities will decarbonise and switch to all-electric technologies and itrsquos essential for businesses and communities to start planning now for the transition to a cleaner and greener future.To find out more about the Green Economy Fund and the projects it supports visit: www.spenergynetworks gef

title: borders-performer-dances-way-stardom
story: THE stage is calling for one talented Borders performer after he wows talent scouts in London.Originally from Newton St Boswell, Gareth Williams is heading for the bright lights after landing a contract with a top talent agency.Gareth was offered representation from MGA Management after impressing talent scouts with his performance at a showcase for industry professionals at Londons Soho Theatre.Twenty-year-old Gareth recently graduated from The MGA Academy of Performing Arts in Edinburgh with a BAMusical Theatre qualication.And the former Earlston High School pupil has recently moved to London to begin auditioning for roles.Gareth said: ldquoAfter my first day at The MGA Academy, I knew it was going to be the quickest three years of my le. The whole experience has been incredible.ldquoItrsquos been hard work, but the teaching has been second to none and Irsquove had the chance to perform in lots of amazing shows.ldquoIrsquove always loved performing and to think Irsquom going to be able to make a living singing and dancing is a dream come true.ldquoFor the past few months, Irsquove been travelling down to London on a regular basis to audition for jobs so decided to move down permanently after graduating.ldquoItrsquos very exciting. Staff at The MGA Academy really prepared me for the audition process - they run special audition classes which give you an insight into what itrsquos like, so you know what to expect.Garethrsquos final performance with The MGA Academy was in a production of Little Shop of Horrors at Leith Theatre directed by Drew Gowland and choreographed by Murray Grant, co-founders of The MGA Academy.Gareth added: ldquoIt was brilliant to end my time at The MGA Academy on such a high note. I love performing at Leith Theatre and it was a really inspiring to get to work with Drew and Murray as there is nothing they canrsquot do, and they offer great advice on how to give the best performance possible.Drew Gowland, co-founder and managing director of The MGA Academy, said: ldquoEveryone at The MGA Academy is incredibly proud of Gareth, and all he has achieved during his three years with us.ldquoFor more than a decade, we have been providing students like Gareth with exceptional training on par with Londonrsquos leading dance and drama schools.ldquoOur training has allowed our graduates to build successful international careers on stage and screen and we wish Gareth all the very best.ldquoWe are currently holding auditions for courses starting in September  and would welcome applications from anyone with similar aspirations to Gareth.Seven young performers from the Borders were chosen to go to MGA last year with more expected to join as the  students.They will be hoping to follow in the footsteps of Gareth and another recent graduate Scottish Disney film star Thomas Doherty.To apply for a place at The MGA Academy of Performing Arts, visit www.themgaacademy apply

title: climate-change-comes-focus-beyond-borders-festival
story: CLIMATE change will come into focus at this yearrsquos Beyond Borders International Festival in Innerleithen.Since , Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times photographer Josh Haner has worked across the globe documenting the pressing and wide-ranging realities of global warming. And this year, events are being held in the Borders to discuss his work ndash which is currently being displayed at the Summerhall Corner Gallery in Edinburgh.The exhibition combines the drama of drone footage from the air with the intimacy of still images from the ground.New York Times director of photography Meaghan Looram said: ldquoWersquore examining quite a dire issue with climate change, but the way wersquore showing it is alluring and beautul.ldquoPhotography allows us to draw people into stories that might be dficult, or easy to ignore, to get them to care about a tough issue.Photographer Josh Haner added: ldquoIt can be problematicyou over-aestheticise the impact of an issue and the sad, real-world impact it has on people across the world.ldquoYou want to draw readers in, but not create something beautul at the cost of the reality beneath it.President of The New York Times Company, Stephen Dunbar-Johnson will appear at the Beyond Borders International Festival at Traquair House on August  alongside other guests to discuss the images.Founder of Beyond Borders Scotland Mark Muller said that showcasing the exhibition in Scotland would provide a  for people to engage with the concerns surrounding climate change.He said: ldquoPhotojournalism is a powerful medium through which to examine the wide-ranging impact of climate change around the world, and with this exhibition and discussion series, we seek to provide erse opportunities for discussion and exchange about this pressing global issue.For more information visit: www.beyondbordersscotland

title: fiery-demise-de-39-il-st-ronan-39-s-games-week
story: THERE is a saying that frequents Border Festivals ndash lsquoitrsquos better felt that teltrsquo.After watching the enchanting Cleikum Ceremony and hearing of the legend of St Ronan, an eighth century monk who overcame evil, I am intrigued by this sacred pastime honoured by the people of Innerleithen for generations.I decided to hail the legend with the residents of this Border town and tell the story by ing to witness the fiery demise of the dersquoil on Saturday.Early evening dusk had fallen as I arrived in Innerleithen with my family, and the sky was growing dark in the distance, a signal to residents to gather for a spiritual sacrice.The heavy downpour the night before had failed to dampen the spirits of St Ronanrsquos people, who turned out in droves to witness the colourful pageant on Saturday morning.Around  children walked through the streets of Innerleithen with colourful blooms in hand. It would be hard not to notice the single imposing figure of the dersquoil amongst the floral sea of youngsters.John Cockburn, clad in a black cloak and hood, carried the fiery red head of the dersquoil mounted on the top of a stout pole draped in red cloth. Itrsquos an eerily unnerving sight that Irsquom sure sent shivers down the spine of many since it was carved in .To the sounds of the pipes and trumpets, local bands joined the parade which halted briefly near the top of Waverley Road for Dux Boy Aaron Glendinning to hang a wreath at the wall plaque commemorating John Euman, who acted as Master of Ceremonies at the Cleikum for almost  years.This ceremony was repeated at the plaques on the wall of the Burgh Chambers to former Games Chairman Walker McLaren and John A Anderson, one of the instigators of the Cleikum Ceremony.An act of kindness was carried out at the end of the parade as children handed their flowers to committee members which would be delivered to local hospitals.The procession, which opened the nd Anniversary of St Ronanrsquos Border Games, took the form of a massed bands display. St Ronanrsquos Silver Band and Peebles Burgh Silver Band combined to present a most impressive march along Innerleithen High Street just after the Race Roond the Toon.Large crowds lined both sides of the High Street to witness this spectacle. The march played was The Pride of Princes Street. Huge crowds gathered on both sides of the street to support both of Innerleithenrsquos fine bands and to enjoy the music at this yearrsquos Beating of the Retreat.Presiding over the performance was the President of St Ronans Border Games Alan Patterson along with St Ronan and the Dux Girl, Standard Bearer Ronan Caine and Lass Caitlin Urquhart, their supporters, Principal Guest Geraint Florida-James, and his we Sarah, the monks, and the dersquoil.The two town bands marched on together under the expert direction Band Sergeant David Lindsay playing Scotland the Brave. The Pipe Band then performed an excellent Drummerrsquos Call followed by the traditional Retreat marches Greens Hills of Tyrol, The Battles Oer and Lochanside.Next the Silver Band played an upbeat version of the Queen hit, Fat Bottomed Girls which featured one of the bandrsquos percussionists, Cameron McCreadie, on drum kit and soprano cornet player, Simon Railton, as soloists.The Pipe Band followed on with a rendition of their new competition medley set comprising a iety of time signatures, featuring an emotional arrangement of the slow air Mingulay Boat Song.More marches back and forth had the crowds clapping and tapping their feet before it was time for the combined piece, which was a beautul arrangement of The Rose of Kelvingrove featuring Pipe Major Gillie as soloist. The Silver Band then rendered Sunset with Callum Anderson and Callum Robb sounding the calls. The hymn tune Eventide was played by principal cornet player, Callum Robb, and conducted by Band Secretary Keith Belleville.Games President Alan Patterson then gave permission for the Bands to take their leave. To resounding applause, the bands marched off playing On, StRonans, On!.There was only one important task that remained, the matter of the dersquoil. We were honorary torch bearers lighting the way for our neighbours the St Ronanites, to burn an effigy of the dersquoil.I quickly ran to the High Street for a prime view of the black cloaked carrier of the dersquoil, monks dressed in their habits chanting and punching their croziers in the air, Standard Bearer Ronan carrying the Blue Banner. The magic of this ancient tale was brought to le. I can only compare it to watching the village mob with torchlights off to kill the beast in the classic Disney film.The friendly Innerleithen mob halts on Hall Street and the dersquoil strangely disappears out of sight.I think of the Cleikum Ceremony and remark to my husband, who carried out the duties of the Dux Boy in, how nice it is that the old customs and traditions exist today, said exactly as it was since its inception in .He recalls word for word the outgoing speech of the Dux Boy which makes me think back to the words of Principal Guest Geraint Florida-James: ldquoInnerleithen and the Games will be in your DNA forever. Never a truer word. You can take the man out of Innerleithen but yoursquoll never take Innerleithen out of the boy!We begin the climb of Curly Hill to the soul-stirring sounds of the Pipe Band. It is dark and the fire-lit torches have been extinguished. The climb feels never-ending and locals start to sing On St Ronanrsquos On. We finally reach the top and, as I look out over the valley, it is simply breathtaking. Some things are better felt that telt.My eyes are drawn to the dark figure that sits on the pyre. A haunting figure approaches bearing a flame, St Ronan has ed in the form of Aaron Glendinning. The pyre bursts into flames and the crowds on the hillside cheer the effigyrsquos fiery demise. Fireworks then light up the dark sky.The dersquoil is now in ashes and the evil spirit has been banished once more. And I, along with the people of Innerleithen, head safely home after truly enchanting evening.

title: cyclists-set-leg-lavender-touch
story: A CYCLING team which has raised tens of thousands of pounds for charity is preparing for its toughest challenge yet.The Over The Hill cyclists are in serious training ahead of their  Border Settlements which will see them complete  miles over three days.The nine-man team - which includes Keith Irvine, Stevie Halls, Sinclair Paterson, Ronnie Murray, Josh Irvine, Kevin Mania, Alan Brown, Doug Welsh and Chris Lightfoot - are tackling the route for the Lavender Touch, a charity which raises funds for people in the Scottish Borders living with cancer.The team have previously cycled  miles from Settle in Yorkshire to Galashiels in aid of Prostate Scotland in , and  miles for the Rowan Boland Memorial Trust in .Stevie Halls said: "The team, which has an age range of mid-s to over , will be passing through over  towns, villages and hamlets in a journey of  miles across the Borders."The route mirrors the geographic reach of the Lavender Touch and although our trip will only last three days, the impact we hope to raise through sponsorship and donations will allow the Lavender Touch to continue to support patients for years to come."We will be supported across the Borders by a tour bus which will follow the route and stop off at many towns and villages where the Lavender Touch volunteers will be holding a number of events to promote the charitys work."The cyclists head off on Friday, August  and hope to reach Gala Cricket Club before the close of play on until Sunday, August .Local businesses can advertise on the side of tour bus -interested, contact Keith Irvine .Donations can be made to the Over the Hills team at www.lavendertouch project over_the_hill_elite_riders

title: garden-delights-opens-peebles
story: A NEW community garden in Peebles was officially opened last week.Tesco store manager Tracy Wilson was given the honour of cutting the ribbon at the Gutterbluids Societyrsquos Dovecot Community Garden.A grant from the Tescos Bags for Help scheme along with local donations helped fund the project on land at the junction of Dovecot Road and March Street.Andrew Fraser, secretary of Peebles Gutterbluids Society told us: "The project would not have been possible without a pound grant received from Tescorsquos Bags of Help Scheme, and the firmrsquos willingness to allow the project to go ahead on their land."The pound grant, plus a few generous local donations, paid for the  small, ornamental trees which were required for the garden."Tescorsquos local Community Champion, Pauline Weir, was very supportive of the project and was keen that bench-seats should be included in the plans."Two bench seats were also donated by local iniduals and have been refurbished, plus two new seats were kindly donated, one by the Rotary Club of Peebles, and the other by private donors."Gutterbluids Society members and a few friends planted out the five groves of trees early last December.And each of the saplings was in blossom this spring.As well as its aesthetic appeal the new garden is also benefitting nature.Mr Fraser added: ldquoThe grass in amongst the tree groves has been left deliberately to grow, providing a natural area for pollenating insects, etc, and a surprising number of wild flowers are growing there."Our bench-seats are proving popular, - and not only for human use."As a result we have had to install lsquopigeon perchesrsquo behind two of the seats, in a bid to stop them perching on the seat backs and defacing them. Thankfully, it seems to have worked.Peebles Gutterbluids Society is most grateful for all the local help and support received during the creation of the community garden.

title: former-pm-may-invited-relax-selkirk-walking-festival
story: FORMER Prime Minister Theresa May has been invited to put Brexit behind her with a walk in the Borders.The -year-old moved out of  Downing Street last week following a turbulent three years in office.Mrs May has come under fire from all sides as Britain attempted to negotiate its way out Europe - eventually leading to her resigning and being replaced by Boris Johnson.As Parliament went into summer recess last week, Mrs May and her husband, Philip, jetted off on holiday for Lake Garda in northern Italy.But shes also received an invite to take in some of the planned hikes at this years Scottish Borders Walking Festival.Mrs May received the invitation as well as the colourful -page brochure from former Walk-it guide Dougie Purves.He told us: "If anyone can benefit from some peaceful time in the hills around Selkirk its Theresa May."Politics can be put aside during the festival so everyone can escape into our beautul countryside."Im sure spending a week here for the Festival would do Mrs May the world of good."Selkirk and the valleys of Ettrick and Yarrow host the th Borders Walking Festival from Saturday, September  until Saturday, September .A packed programme of scenic hikes, gentle strolls and historic trails are accompanied by an evening schedule of dances, talks and other entertainment.Although Parliament s on September , Mrs May hasnt ruled out a walk to the Megget Stane, Three Brethren or Witchieknowe.In her non-committal response to Mr Purvess invite, she said: "The Scottish Borders are beautul and always enjoyable to explore."I am sure the Festival will be great fun for those attending the walks."The th Borders Walking Festival hosts  dferent walks, ranging from two miles up to  miles.

title: creative-stage-edinburgh-s-fringe

title: caddon-claims-trophy-yellow-jersey
story: A CLOVENFORDS design studio can claim the yellow jersey after producing a stunning trophy for this years Tour of Britain.The Scottish Borders will host an entire stage of the road race on Sunday, September .And the winner of the gruelling  kilometre stage will be presented with a commemorative trophy from Caddon Design.The stunning glass trophy with oak plinth has been made by Kenny Scott.He was joined this week at Scotts View by local business councillor Mark Rowley for the unveiling.Councillor Rowley said: ldquoThe Scottish Borders has hosted the Tour of Britain six times in the past  years, but this September will be the first time that wersquove had both the start and finish of a stage, and also the whole route is within the Scottish Borders area."This gives us a fantastic opportunity to showcase more of the area than before and for even greater economic benefits.ldquoWe felt it was only fitting to recognise this with a special trophy for the stage winner and this design will act as a reminder to whichever rider crosses the finish line first in Kelso of a memorable day in the beautul Scottish Borders."The OVO Energy Tour of Britain begins in Glasgowrsquos George Square on Saturday, September , finishing eight days later in Manchester city centre.ITV will once again screen live free-to-air coverage from start to finish of each stage in the UK, along with a nightly highlights programme of the best of the action.

title: push-parents-bin-disposable-nappies
story: A PIONEERING project in Peebles is hoping to re-potty-train parents in a bid to help the planet.It is estimated that the average child will go through as many as , disposable nappies before they pull on their first pair of pants.And that the throw-away toilet aids account for around three per-cent of all household waste that goes to landfill.Environmental charity Change Works in Peebles is hoping to persuade parents to make ato reusable nappies.And they are offering heavily discounted start packs as part of their conversion.Morag Cockburn from Change Works told us: ldquoWe hope to provide parents and expectant parents with more information about the practicalities of reusable nappies, as well as their many benefits."Switching to reusable nappies can be a daunting prospect but the starter pack is an ideal way to test before you invest."Change Works in Peebles can also provide advice to families on reducing energy bills and staying warm at home, all the more important with young children in the household.Change Works believe parents will save up to pound by making the change.Modern reusable nappies are more absorbent than the pre-s towelling ieties, and are more comfortable.Change Works in Peebles launch the reusable nappy starter kits at their headquarters on Wednesday, August , between am and noon.Morag added: "Parents, carers and expectant parents are warmly invited to drop in and find out about reusable nappies over a coffee and cake."The starter packs, worth almost pound, includes three types of nappies, accessories and an instruction guide will be available for only pound.Change Works in Peebles is funded by Scottish Borders Council, Changeworks and the Scottish Government until March .

title: results-due-condition-gala-39-s-iconic-stand
story: THE crumbling condition of an iconic football stand in Galashiels will be revealed next month.Engineers have spent the past couple of weeks carrying out drilling tests on the Peter Womersley designed stand at Netherdale.And their samples are about to be tested under laboratory conditions to determine the scale of problems.The A-listed building has been closed since the start of the year due to concerns over falling masonry.And Gala Fairydean Rovers have brought in a modern replacement structure to seat supporters for their Lowland League matches.A spokesman for the club said: "We all have our fingers crossed that the problems with the stand arent as bad as was first feared."There is visible deterioration and conservation work is needed - but we hope the test results show that the structure is sound and we can get our stand back in the not too distant future."The health and safety of our staff and supporters is paramount, so the stand will remain closed until all repair works are completed."The Netherdale grandstand, built in , was one of the first football stadiums in the UK to use a cantilever design.Womersleys revolutionary design attracts visitors from around the world.Scottish Borders Council is supporting Gala Fairydean Rovers with the required repairs.A spokesman for the local authority said: ldquoA contractor is currently carrying out intrusive investigation works on the Netherdale stand.ldquoThis work is expected to be completed within the next week, with laboratory tests to follow which will be part of a report presented to Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in autumn.ldquoThis report will include information on the extent of the repairs required, and assist the club with any funding applications it plans to submit to restore the stand.
